results.title: Hello, Mr. Webb!
results.brief_description: Film made by the Department of Agriculture’s film unit to promote itself by showing who they are, where they are located and what they do on a daily basis. The tone of the piece is very light and it contains numerous jokes relating to the fact that it is the film unit making a film about the film unit. Also contains general information about film editing machines (Moviola) and how they operate. Brief footage of the Spring St end of Bourke street circa 1977.

results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Drainage
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
results.description: Green Fingers was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

In this episode, ‘Drainage’, gardener Rod Cantrill describes the importance of well-drained soil in the home garden. Cantrill demonstrates how to lay agricultural drainage pipes to remove excess water from the soil, and how to raise garden beds as an alternative method. The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane

results.title: Centenary of Bright
results.brief_description:
Begins with landscape shots outside of Bright, before focusing on the centenary celebrations, including crowds and reinactments of life in Bright 100 years ago. Film then follows a parade, highlighting the numerous floats involved.

Good footage of 20m high tress being cut down as part of a carnival.

Deputy Premier A.G Rylah unviels the Bright centenary Cairn, gives speech about the importnace of young people in a community.

Film nicely shot, with vibrant colours.

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
description_for_label: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: Doubts and reassessment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Architecture at the Crossroads Series”.
Part One of a series which examines the main themes in world architecture today. The series looks at the work of architects who are at the centre of the current debate, and introduces some younger architects who are beginning to make a name for themselves. Against a background of disenchantment with modern architecture throughout the world, and the justifiable belief that modern cities are a failure, the series starts by outlining the exciting changes that are now taking place, and examining what has brought them about.

results.title: Houses Fit for People
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Architecture at the Crossroads Series”.
Part Eight of a series which examines the main themes in world architecture today. The series looks at the work of architects who are at the centre of the current debate, and introduces some younger architects who are beginning to make a name for themselves. Part Eight deals with domestic housing. Most famous architects are concerned with commercial and institutional architecture. Ordinary people have to live in “junk” but there are signs that housing design is undergoing a change for the better. In the suburbs of Paris and London, a more humane architecture is beginning to emerge which challenges the monotony of the “new town” ideal.

results.title: New Market Places
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Architecture at the Crossroads Series”.
Part Four of a series which examines the main themes in world architecture today. The series looks at the work of architects who are at the centre of the current debate, and introduces some younger architects who are beginning to make a name for themselves. Part Four deals with “communal spaces”. All over the world pedestrian precincts, shopping malls and hotel lobbies are replacing the traditional village squares. Architects have realised that more places are required to satisfy people’s love of spectacle. From America are coming new atrias, open spaces for people to gather. Everywhere new museums are being built that are no longer just housing the treasures of the past: they have become places for social and community activities.
